body: @jasongrout this implementation addresses both the model and view order issues.
https://github.com/jakearchibald/es6-promise maybe a good polyfill...
https://github.com/tildeio/rsvp.js is probably better
Rebase somehow butchered this up...  Fixing...
Rebase fixed
From gitter discussion I'm all from ES6 and if at some point we need a transpiler, ES6->ES5 I'm not against.
I addressed all of my concerns in a pull request to Jon: https://github.com/jdfreder/ipython/pull/22

@jasongrout how do you feel about wrapping errors?  I really miss that feature of the .net language family.  

``` vb
try
    raise new Exception('error1')
catch e as Exception
    raise new IOException(e)
end try
```

for Javascript we could do something like

``` js
new Error({msg: 'Higher level message.', original: error});
```

where error is a lower level `Error`.

I looked online for a JS intrinsic way of doing this, but couldn't find anything.  I think using an object in the Error's message to contain both the new message and the original error could work, but I'm not convinced it's obvious enough that it should be a practice we partake in...

Is WrapppedError a good name?  Possible alternatives:
- StackedError
- ErrorStack
- NestedError
- WrapError
- ChainedError
- ErrorChain
Rebased

Our testing framework was driving me crazy today!  I was having a lot of trouble tracking down a few bugs because of it.  Instead of tracking down the bugs, I thought my time would be better spent improving the output of the Javascript test framework.  Output that looked like this:

```
PASS _dom_classes can be used to remove a class.
PASS Display container child executed with correct output.
PASS Parent container not displayed.
FAIL Child displayed.
#    type: assert
#    file: /home/jon/ipython/IPython/html/tests/widgets/widget_box.js:78
#    code: 'Child displayed.');
#    subject: false

Captured console.log:
    Default extension for cell metadata editing loaded.
    Raw Cell Format toolbar preset loaded.
    Slideshow extension for metadata editing loaded.
    no checkpoint done
    Session: kernel_created (c2660f88-d30c-4968-8d70-025ac1f50220)
    Starting WebSockets: ws://127.0.0.1:8888/api/kernels/a5ab36f0-764d-4d48-a592-83727e889593

    Kernel: kernel_starting (a5ab36f0-764d-4d48-a592-83727e889593)

```

Now looks like this:

```

FAIL Child displayed.
#    type: assert

Captured console.log:

    Slideshow extension for metadata editing loaded.
    no checkpoint done
    Session: kernel_created (c2660f88-d30c-4968-8d70-025ac1f50220)
    Starting WebSockets: ws://127.0.0.1:8888/api/kernels/a5ab36f0-764d-4d48-a592-83727e889593

    Kernel: kernel_starting (a5ab36f0-764d-4d48-a592-83727e889593)
    Kernel: kernel_starting (a5ab36f0-764d-4d48-a592-83727e889593)

    Kernel: kernel_ready (a5ab36f0-764d-4d48-a592-83727e889593)
    Error {
      "message": "Couldn't process display msg for model id 'd6c660a3cc49410196c5748f07f3d00b'",
      "error_stack": [
          "message": "Class undefined not found in registry "
          "message": "Couldn't create a view for model id 'd6c660a3cc49410196c5748f07f3d00b'"
          "message": "Could not display view"
          "message": "Couldn't process display msg for model id 'd6c660a3cc49410196c5748f07f3d00b'"
      ]
    }
```

All thanks to a log and error hook that JSONifys the objects before they are printed.

While I was at it, I also cleaned up the Page Error message, so it's properly indented and the `?v=32741073284` junk isn't visible at the end of the trace URLs.
where are we with this now?

Hey @jasongrout there's a nasty race condition with parent widgets and their calling of display on their children.  Sometimes display is called before the first state push.  I checked the Promise logic and it's sound as-is.  The problem is in the assumptions we make of the back-end sending the state message before the display message.  By adding some additional promise logic to make sure a `set_state` happened at least once before the display, I was able to get the tests passing _mostly_.  However, I don't think this is the right fix, instead I should send an initial state along with the comm open message.
Ok I just rebased.  Commit f49ff30 has my kludgy debugging logic and log statements.  I'll remove this commit and replace it with the proper one.  I just pushed it so you could see what I was up to.

Ok, the last commit gets a us a bit closer, there's still a problem somewhere.  For some reason I'm seeing a MathJax error being raised as a result of the `set_state` message `ReferenceError: Can't find variable: MathJax`...  strange.
Looks like something broke in a rebase!

I thought we always opened the comm and then immediately sent a set_state message.  Later we would send a display message.  Since the order of messages is guaranteed, and promises guarantee order of execution, it should work, right?  What am I not understanding?

> Since the order of messages is guaranteed, and promises guarantee order of execution, it should work, right? What am I not understanding?

Everything you say is correct, and your confusion is the same confusion I am having.  If you look Travis's output for the debugging commit: https://travis-ci.org/ipython/ipython/jobs/40110666#L4126 you'll see that a display message is received before the initial state.  I haven't pin pointed why this happens.  It happens consistently in all of the same places:

```
Captured console.log:
    Default extension for cell metadata editing loaded.
    Raw Cell Format toolbar preset loaded.
    Slideshow extension for metadata editing loaded.
    no checkpoint done
    Session: kernel_created (79138bf5-1dd7-4b54-a7e4-90e7e401b2a2)
    Starting WebSockets: ws://127.0.0.1:8888/api/kernels/e3fdb2e2-3c80-4877-b869-34593d24de64
    Kernel: kernel_connected (e3fdb2e2-3c80-4877-b869-34593d24de64)
    Kernel: kernel_starting (e3fdb2e2-3c80-4877-b869-34593d24de64)
    Kernel: kernel_starting (e3fdb2e2-3c80-4877-b869-34593d24de64)
    Kernel: kernel_ready (e3fdb2e2-3c80-4877-b869-34593d24de64)
    Kernel: kernel_ready (e3fdb2e2-3c80-4877-b869-34593d24de64)
    MSG: display 0 for model id '9ab7a38211f54054a2b1ad6335454263'
    MSG: update 1 for model id '9ab7a38211f54054a2b1ad6335454263'
    MSG: update 0 for model id '419c4566304847d69bfaf9f5b7f68003'
    MSG: update proc 1 for model id '9ab7a38211f54054a2b1ad6335454263'
    MSG: update proc 0 for model id '419c4566304847d69bfaf9f5b7f68003'
         -----
         STATE: {"value":false}
         -----
         STATE: {"value":false}
    MSG: display proc 0 for model id '9ab7a38211f54054a2b1ad6335454263'
    Session: kernel_killed (79138bf5-1dd7-4b54-a7e4-90e7e401b2a2)
```

Quick explanation of the above:
**MSG: display** : a display message was received and a Promise was created.
**MSG: update** : an update message was received and a Promise was created.
**MSG: display proc** : the Promise contents of the display message are being executed.
**MSG: update proc** : the Promise contents of the update message are being executed.
where update is synonymous for set_state.
Can you reproduce it by hand?
No, I haven't been able to reproduce it by hand.

I think it's either
- a problem with the tests
- a subtle timing issue with the framework itself
@jasongrout using `slimerjs` instead of the `phantomjs` back-end, _more_ of the tests pass... hmph...  _Checking to see if rsvp.js is compatible with phantomjs._

I'm really on the struggle bus with this one...  I've verified that the back-end is sending the messages in the correct order:

```
63c97c0af7f8459f9158bd0a0fc76e1f
{'state': {'_view_name': u'CheckboxView', 'color': u'', '_view_module': u'', 'height': u'', 'disabled': False, 'visible': True, 'border_radius': u'', 'border_width': u'', 'background_color': u'', 'font_style': '', 'width': u'', 'version': 0, 'font_family': u'', '_dom_classes': [], 'description': u'Title', 'border_color': u'', 'padding': u'', 'font_weight': '', 'border_style': '', 'font_size': u'', 'msg_throttle': 3, '_css': [], 'value': True, 'margin': u''}, 'method': 'update'}
b4d6020417c3455fb74e986d91e1244b
{'state': {'_view_name': u'ToggleButtonView', 'color': u'', '_view_module': u'', 'height': u'', 'disabled': False, 'visible': True, 'border_radius': u'', 'border_width': u'', 'background_color': u'', 'font_style': '', 'button_style': '', 'width': u'', 'version': 0, 'font_family': u'', '_dom_classes': [], 'description': u'Title', 'border_color': u'', 'padding': u'', 'font_weight': '', 'border_style': '', 'font_size': u'', 'msg_throttle': 3, '_css': [], 'value': True, 'margin': u''}, 'method': 'update'}
63c97c0af7f8459f9158bd0a0fc76e1f
{'method': 'display'}
b4d6020417c3455fb74e986d91e1244b
{'method': 'display'}
```

Something's wrong with how the front-end is handling them.  The state is definitely **NOT** set at the time of view creation because 

``` js
                console.log(' _view_name ' + model.get('_view_name'));
                console.log(' _view_module ' + model.get('_view_module'));
```

when `create_view` gets executed yields 

```
_view_name undefined
_view_module undefined
```

A cool side note, I wrote an `interact` function for our CasperJS tests that allows you to spawn an interactive JS shell at any point in the test execution.  I've been using it to get a closer look at what's happening in PhantomJS.

I've verified the messages are received in the correct order at the lowest level in the front-end

```
    update
    display
```

Something **must** be wrong with the way I'm using Promises...
Ok, I've pushed what I have as of tonight (debug and prints and all).  I'll continue with this tomorrow...
New components PR https://github.com/ipython/ipython-components/pull/43

Brief summary of what I've found:
- Both testing environments (slimerjs and phantomjs) fail.  I've been focusing on the `widget_bool.js` tests.
- The messages sent from the back-end are in the correct order, that is: comm open, set state, then display.
- The slimerjs environment receives the messages in the correct order but the phantomjs environment appears to receive them in incorrect order, but I think this may be a problem with the `console.log` capturing and we may be seeing the log messages out of order.  The Javascript context that the tests run in is different than the page being tested. 
- because of this, slimerjs seems to be the ideal environment to test with, but I ran into another problem when adding log statements everywhere.  Once a certain number of log statements are executed, the slimerjs environment throws a strange io error.  Phantomjs does not throw an error..
- I think the state unpacking logic is the most complicated, but I checked states going in vs states comming out, and it seems to work great.
- executing the test code (python) that the test framework uses works great in Chrome!  I  ran it 10-15 times.
  -I tried changing the test framework to wait for the widget selectors to appear in the dom, but after 10s it times out because the widgets never appear
@jasongrout I just pushed the commit that adds the polyfill- I had forgotten to push it over the weekend.
